awd_titl_txt: Information Technology Skill Standards, 2020 and Beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
In 2003, the ATE National Workforce Center for Emerging Technologies (NWCET) developed and published the "Building a Foundation for Tomorrow: Skill Standards for Information Technology". This document has not been updated since 2003, and it no longer aligns with current information technology (IT) industry needs. This project will develop a new employer-led and verified IT Skill Standards document for the top eight to ten IT industry job clusters supporting positions requiring a two-year or a four-year applied IT degree. Initial discussions with industry experts have identified at least four new job clusters that did not exist in 2003, along with an additional five to six job clusters that need to be updated. Skill standards make IT careers more accessible as they provide transparency regarding the knowledge, skills and performance standards needed for success in the industry, and educators use skill standards to develop relevant curricular materials to better prepare students for the workplace.

This project will develop a future-facing set of IT Skill Standards for the most critical IT job clusters, led by employer subject matter experts. In addition to creating a set of skill standards for each job cluster, the standards within each job cluster will be stratified by the top four to eight critical work functions. The project will also compile a list of the certifications valued by employers as of the date of publication. For each cluster, a national group of educators and Business and Industry Leadership Team (BILT) members will determine which portions of the standards apply to two-year and four-year programs, to facilitate ease of use in development of employer aligned curriculum. These stratifications will assist both employers and educators to more easily apply the standards. Subject matter experts will be asked to predict trends in IT and the knowledge and skills that will likely to be needed to support emerging trends. It is expected that this effort will increase the use and longevity of the developed standards. Dissemination efforts will use ATE Central and the Convergence Technology Center website, will feature multiple strategies to increase awareness of the skill standards, and will provide tools for their use and application.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
IT Skill Standards 2020 and Beyond Project was an NSF ATE grant that develop and updated future-facing IT Skill Standards for critical IT job clusters, which were identified by a group of >100 national IT Thought Leader (TL) Subject Matter Experts (SMEs). The last time IT skill standards were comprehensively addressed was 2003; standards were seriously outdated.

Thought Leaders selected seven clusters of focus from roughly 14 potential job clusters discussed in 4 meetings.  Consensus was then obtained across meetings by multiple questionnaires similar to using the Delphi analytical method.  And, several new clusters were identified that were not present in 2003.  The work focused on Data Analytics, Data Management and Engineering, Software Development, IT Project Management, Infrastructure Management and Engineering, Technical Support, and Cybersecurity.  However, due to the existence of major ongoing NSA work in Cybersecurity Education, this project developed only a Cyber skill set applicable to any discipline rather than duplicate work. The project coordinated work with the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education, which is funded on a continuing basis, not through a grant that will sunset.

IT Skill Standards were created and published  and then updated due to advice from the annual Review Board for the Project.  Also note that Skill Standards are not appropriate for emerging areas such as Artificial Intelligence that are still rapidly emerging although the Business & Industry Leadership Team (BILT) process developed by the National Convergence Technology Center is appropriate for developing the KSAs that can be expected to change at least annually.  The ITSS project used the BILT model as the evaluative engine for its work.

The ITSS leadership team is especially proud that the resulting Skill Standards, both the original and the updates, were recognized by the Texas Skill Standards Board and are available on their website for use by colleges in Texas and beyond.

The Skill Standards product delivered for each job cluster included the employer highly- prioritized Knowledge, Skills, Abilities and Tasks; Prioritized Employability Skills; Key Performance Criteria for each Task (how good is good enough for each highly prioritized Task); and developed student learning outcomes for each highly prioritized KSA.  All delivered Skill Standards Products were archived on ATE Central, were uploaded to a Google public folder that was highly promoted prior to sunset, and were given to the National IT Innovation Center (NITIC), the current NSF IT National Center as a basis for further work.

The project suffered through the shutdowns and travel restrictions of COVID, but it was able to proceed by adapting to using virtual web meetings instead of the planned and preferable face-to-face employer SME  meetings that had been conveniently been planned to be held in three 3 geographically separated parts of the country per cluster.  Additionally, due to COVID and workers working from home or furloughed, it was difficult to recruit employer SMEs. The project did ultimately involve over 260 employer IT SMEs. 

Further, the leadership realized that the Skill Standards process developed for IT could   apply to any technical discipline. Due to interest in the process encouraged, in part, by numerous conference presentations and webinars, the project documented the Skill Standards Development process for use by any technical discipline and held six 3-day ITSS Summits that were open to 2-year colleges/teams from any technical discipline.  In total, 109 attended these summits from 44 colleges distributed across 21 states.  Further, the team converted the ITSS Summit presentations to a virtual self-directed Skill Standards course that lives on past sunset.

Finally, the project created a 34-page ITSS Impacts Book summarizing the work of the grant as well as 169-page Resouce document with all documentation and resulting deliverables. All relevant materials and results were given to the NITIC Center as well being archived at ATE Central and on the Google public drive.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Ann Beheler
por.por_txt_cntn:
IT Skill Standards 2020 and Beyond Project was an NSF ATE grant that develop and updated future-facing IT Skill Standards for critical IT job clusters, which were identified by a group of 100 national IT Thought Leader (TL) Subject Matter Experts (SMEs). The last time IT skill standards were comprehensively addressed was 2003; standards were seriously outdated.


Thought Leaders selected seven clusters of focus from roughly 14 potential job clusters discussed in 4 meetings. Consensus was then obtained across meetings by multiple questionnaires similar to using the Delphi analytical method. And, several new clusters were identified that were not present in 2003. The work focused on Data Analytics, Data Management and Engineering, Software Development, IT Project Management, Infrastructure Management and Engineering, Technical Support, and Cybersecurity. However, due to the existence of major ongoing NSA work in Cybersecurity Education, this project developed only a Cyber skill set applicable to any discipline rather than duplicate work. The project coordinated work with the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education, which is funded on a continuing basis, not through a grant that will sunset.


IT Skill Standards were created and published and then updated due to advice from the annual Review Board for the Project. Also note that Skill Standards are not appropriate for emerging areas such as Artificial Intelligence that are still rapidly emerging although the Business & Industry Leadership Team (BILT) process developed by the National Convergence Technology Center is appropriate for developing the KSAs that can be expected to change at least annually. The ITSS project used the BILT model as the evaluative engine for its work.


The ITSS leadership team is especially proud that the resulting Skill Standards, both the original and the updates, were recognized by the Texas Skill Standards Board and are available on their website for use by colleges in Texas and beyond.


The Skill Standards product delivered for each job cluster included the employer highly- prioritized Knowledge, Skills, Abilities and Tasks; Prioritized Employability Skills; Key Performance Criteria for each Task (how good is good enough for each highly prioritized Task); and developed student learning outcomes for each highly prioritized KSA. All delivered Skill Standards Products were archived on ATE Central, were uploaded to a Google public folder that was highly promoted prior to sunset, and were given to the National IT Innovation Center (NITIC), the current NSF IT National Center as a basis for further work.


The project suffered through the shutdowns and travel restrictions of COVID, but it was able to proceed by adapting to using virtual web meetings instead of the planned and preferable face-to-face employer SME meetings that had been conveniently been planned to be held in three 3 geographically separated parts of the country per cluster. Additionally, due to COVID and workers working from home or furloughed, it was difficult to recruit employer SMEs. The project did ultimately involve over 260 employer IT SMEs.


Further, the leadership realized that the Skill Standards process developed for IT could apply to any technical discipline. Due to interest in the process encouraged, in part, by numerous conference presentations and webinars, the project documented the Skill Standards Development process for use by any technical discipline and held six 3-day ITSS Summits that were open to 2-year colleges/teams from any technical discipline. In total, 109 attended these summits from 44 colleges distributed across 21 states. Further, the team converted the ITSS Summit presentations to a virtual self-directed Skill Standards course that lives on past sunset.


Finally, the project created a 34-page ITSS Impacts Book summarizing the work of the grant as well as 169-page Resouce document with all documentation and resulting deliverables. All relevant materials and results were given to the NITIC Center as well being archived at ATE Central and on the Google public drive.
